Are the zones expected to have a trailing "."? Technically this is what an FQDN means but I think this should be called out if it is required since its a common misconception.

I will test it with and without trailing . and if it's necessary I think I will add it on the backend side. But I have managed to create an A record with ipa cli without adding the . after the zone name or adding one before. I think you might want the following regex: "^[a-zA-Z0-9]+[a-zA-Z0-9.-]*[a-zA-Z0-9.]+$"


The dash after the 9 is invalid. Put it at the front/end of the bracketed section so that it doesn't form a range.


Assuming the "-" is removed, this regex allows "\" in FQDNs:


echo www\\google.com | egrep "^[a-zA-Z0-9]+[a-zA-Z0-9\\.]*[a-zA-Z0-9]+$"


nit: This regex technically doesn't allow a trailing "." and that technically is required to be a part of an FQDN (but it is very rare that that is actually used).

I'm writing unit tests, and it seems valid


\\ is necessary. first \ is for escaping the dot, as by default dot matches anything, the second one is necessary for java to escape \


For now I will leave it this way, we can weaken the regexp later if necessary
I have added unit tests to validate the regex. Could you check?
